captions.text: - I think what makes men cry
is the same thing that makes women cry.

It's it feels good to sort
of let yourself feel bad.

- I try to hide it, like
I think most dudes do.

But not because I'm sad,
just because I don't want
people to feel like they need to help.
What Makes Men Cry?
- I honestly can't remember

the last time I cried
in front of somebody.

- Any movie that's sort of
heartfelt or that I'm invested in
will generally have me choking up.

- I think the last time
I cried was at a TV show.

I was watching this HBO mini
series called Olive Kitteridge.

- I can think of the last time
that I like hit something.

But I can't think of
the last time I cried.
- It was about a month and a half ago.
My grandmother had a stroke.
And she died a week or so later.
I cried when I talked to her on the phone.

I basically told her I
loved her for the last time.
- A friend of mine just died.
So I was at the hospital
and that was the last time I cried,
which was last week.
- Radio Live did a story about this family

where they had a breakthrough
with their autistic son.

And I remember just driving
through LA, listening to that,
and just kinda, not just tears welling up,

but kind of sobbing at
some of the moments.
- You know, you go about your life

and then there's something that
reminds you of that person.
It's there. It's never gonna go away.
It's just always gonna,

there's always gonna be
these pits and valleys.
- I'm a person that cries very easily,
and I'm not ashamed of that.
I'm in touch with my emotions.
I think I've always been pretty sensitive

and never felt like it was
a bad thing if I cried.

- A lot of my male friends,
I've never seen them cry.
And I think that society has told them
that they shouldn't cry.

And if they do cry, that
they're somehow less masculine,
somehow less manly.
But I think that's all crap.
- The last time that I cried so much

that I couldn't believe
how much I was crying
was when I moved to Los Angeles
and I left my girlfriend in Chicago.
It was very hard at that time.

And I think that was the
last time that I actually...

And I held it out for so
long before I moved away.
And it was the last time that

we had to get out of the
car at the same time.
I had to go to the airport.
I just lost it.
- Being able to express your emotions
as a man is a good thing.
- The actual physical release of tears,

you just can't help it when
you feel those emotions.
It's just what happens.
- I'm okay with it.
I'm fine being a person that cries.

And often times, I feel
a lot better after I cry.

- You should seek out things
that would cause you to cry

because crying gives
new meaning to things.
Crying allows you to seek the inner self.
- I haven't cried in a year.
It's weird.

How have my eyes not just
like shutdown one day

and just went, fuck
you, I'm just gonna cry?
It's weird.
- When you do cry, you kinda feel like
you've changed a little bit I think.

And that's an important
feeling for anyone to feel.

comments.text:
My girlfriend of 13 months left me for another guy who she said was just a 
"guy friend", and I was depressed but I bottled my emotions up and tried to 
ignore it and hide it. Today (a week later), I woke up and was listening to 
music getting ready to go for a run, and I just started crying my ass off 
for like an hour. It's crazy how strong music can get to you, but it's even 
more crazy how vulnerable a person can get if they try to ignore their 
emotions. Don't be afraid to cry and let it all out. If you don't, you WILL 
breakdown harder than you should.﻿

comments.author: Thomas Aurelius

comments.text:
I'm a guy and I can only remember crying once in the last 8 years. I 
childhood friend of mine drowned the day after our Highschool Graduation. 
At his memorial, they played a slideshow of pictures and had one of the two 
of us that i had out taken on the last day of 5th grade and put on 
instagram when i heard the news. At that moment it hit me that my friend 
had really passed away, and i began sobbing. Before i new it the whole 
group of my other friends and students were also crying. We comforted each 
other in a sensitive moment, and i felt better afterwards. That being said, 
I am not afraid/ashamed and don't feel pressured not to cry infront of 
others. It just takes something serious, like the death of somebody close, 
to get me too cry in the first place. P.s. I'm am 20yrs old and graduated 
in 2013.﻿

comments.text:
I understand how men feel. I may not be a man but i still know. Personality 
and physically wise, I am strong. Most people fear me and when people don't 
for some reason i'm bothered. I'm scared to cry in front of people because 
they might lose their respect for me or even find me weak. No one knows I 
feel this way which is what makes it hurt even more. The saddest thing is 
i've never cried to any of my friends. Only my parents and one true friend 
have seen me cry. I have a lot going on that nobody knows not even my 
parents and sometimes it's hard keeping it in. A few weeks ago was the 
birthday of my dead grandma. My mum told me we wouldn't be able to go to 
her grave and to her I didn't seem bothered but in reality i was broken. 
She was the only one who let me cry and didn't judge. Sometimes I think she 
loved me more than my mum... Anyway I just realized how long this 'essay' 
is and I just want to finish it with a message-

 "Just cry"﻿

Actually, we need to take note that society judge in the context, not the 
crying itself. If a guy cried because he got his ass kicked, then yes, he 
is considered to be less masculine. But if a guy cried because his dog 
died, then it is completely permissible and accepted by society. Not even 
that, but it shows that he is *strong* enough to show that he's *weak*.﻿

comments.text:
i don't do crying the typical way, chocked up and making noises. When i 
disperse saltwater from my eyes i don't even usualy feel sadder then 
normal. Just when i go to bed being alone hits me hard. Then i usualy 
imagine not being alone and have my girlfriend/wife lie beside me. That 
feels somewhat nice but everytime i do that before going to sleep i can't 
stop my tears even though i don't recognise myself as espacially sad in 
that moment. I once thought about intentionelly breaking my mind far enough 
to realisticaly imagine / believe in having a girlfriend. But im scared 
that would turn me into a total nutcase. So i just bear with it till i get 
slain by lightning or hit a by meteor if i luck out so i can peace out.﻿

comments.text:
The last time I cried was wile I was driving with my girlfriend and this 
speeding car almost hit us. She asked what I would do if it had hit us and 
I was alive but she had died. Well I, being one with a vivid imagination, 
thought about it and saw it in my mind and I started crying. The last time 
I cried like hard core was when I had a horribly realistic nightmare about 
my gf getting hit by a car wile riding her bike. It was so real and I was 
up for hours crying in my bed leaving her messages on her phone because her 
phone was on silent and she didn't answer. That only added to the fear that 
maybe it wasn't a dream and I was in denial and was just calling a phone 
that no longer had a owner. It was horrible and just thinking about it 
makes me want to ball up and cry. Well that was my story. 
PS. Driving wile crying is not fun.﻿

comments.author: CzarJuliusIII

comments.text:
*I think its pretty obvious for most that in regards to Men, unlike Women, 
there is a time and place when crying is acceptable, but also times where 
it is not.*

In those cases where its not socially acceptable one should do ones utmost 
to avoid it because it will have negative social consequences *(a board 
meeting at work with high pressure or similar for example)*, but if one 
feel that one has to get it out later. Its just healthy to do so because 
one will feel like a huge weight is lifted off ones shoulders after one has 
"cried out", you will feel more focused and in some cases give you a slight 
feeling of anger which will drive you to continue "moving forwards", so to 
speak. Just do it in the shower where the sound of running water will mask 
the crying and you are in private or in confidence with a person that is 
trustworthy and understanding of both you and the social context of Men 
crying.

In the military, being a squad leader, I have had a few soldiers cry on my 
shoulder and it has always turned out better than with the ones that have 
had it just build up to something worse. Ether towards others or 
themselves. Both being equally negative in a social context if its 
perceived as the person losing it emotionally as Man. For example, if you 
beat someone up *(fisty cuffs, not head stomping)* its one thing and might 
be seen as reasonable in some situations, but if you beat them up in a 
crying like manner it will have the opposite effect even if you win. 
Because there is a difference between losing ones temper and losing it 
emotionally, the latter insinuating a lack of control in a feminine way.

Crying in public because of loss of life in any context, your team losing a 
major sporting event among fans, watching a sad movie and shedding a tear *(aka, 
not crying like a bitch)* etc have become more socially acceptable today 
though. So dont worry about those situations. For most Men its in the 
context of work or danger, specially if you are the only male adult around, 
where its still "socially banned" to cry.﻿
